raw_text:
Van Gogh festival film withdrawn
 
 Murdered director Theo van Gogh's controversial film Submission has been pulled from the Rotterdam Film Festival because of security fears.
 
 It was one of three of his works to be shown as part of a freedom of expression event in tribute to the late film-maker's life. The film is critical of the treatment of women under Islam. Its TV screening is thought to have led to his murder. The 10-day Dutch festival begins on Wednesday. Submission was made with liberal Somali-Dutch politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali and was due to be shown on 30 January. Van Gogh was shot and stabbed to death in November 2004 several months after receiving death threats following Submission's first broadcast on Dutch television. Two of Van Gogh's other films will be shown as planned, including the theatrical world premiere of his last feature 06/05.
 
 Festival director Sandra den Hamer said: "The festival reflects what happens around us and within cinema itself." The festival opens with the French film The 10th District Court, Moments of Trials made by Raymond Depardon. The event sees 14 films competing to win three Top Tiger Awards which aim to introduce promising new talent. New sections added to this year's festival include Cinema of the Future and Cinema of the World, with special focus on Russian and south-east Asian productions. There is also an Iraqi-German offering entitled Underexposure, which looks at life in Iraq after Saddam Hussein.
llama3.2:1b: Murdered director Theo van Gogh's film Submission has been withdrawn from the Rotterdam Film Festival due to security fears. The film was part of a freedom of expression event and was shown as part of a tribute to van Gogh's life. Van Gogh received death threats following the first broadcast, and he was shot in November 2004 before it could be shown. Two other films will be shown as planned, including the world premiere of his last feature.

Two of Van Gogh's other films will still be shown, including its last feature. The festival will continue with 14 competing films for Top Tiger Awards and new sections on Cinema of the Future and Cinema of the World.

The film Submission is part of a freedom-of-expression event for Van Gogh's work and features liberal Somali-Dutch politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali alongside other films. The festival opens with Raymond Depardon's French film "The 10th District Court."

The festival will instead feature three of Van Gogh's works along with other films promoting freedom of expression, including Ayaan Hirsi Ali's documentary on women under Islam and a World War II French court film.
qwen2.5:3b: Van Gogh's controversial film Submission, critical of Islam's treatment of women, was withdrawn from Rotterdam Film Festival due to security concerns following the filmmaker's murder. The festival, marking Theo van Gogh's life, features three films including Submission, screened with his permission by liberal Somali-Dutch politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali. Submission led to van Gogh's fatal shooting in 2004 after receiving threats for its Dutch television broadcast. The festival also shows two of van Gogh’s other works and new sections focusing on Russian and southeast Asian productions.
opencoder:1.5b:
Van Gogh's film withdrawal from the Rotterdam Film Festival has been a critical decision for Theo van Gogh, who was one of the director's three works to be shown as part of a freedom of expression event during which he received a high dose of criticism and punishment.
In addition to his work, Van Gogh also committed himself to producing a film, which he called Submission. The festival director Sandra den Hamer explained that the festival reflects what happens around us and within cinema itself.
The festival opens with the French film "The 10th District Court" from Moments of Trials made by Raymond Depardon. It sees 14 films competing in the Top Tiger Awards for three years, which aim to introduce promising new talent to the world.
A part of the festival director's decision was making a new section for the festival named Cinema of the Future and Cinema of the World, with special focus on productions from Russia and India.
Apart from those movies, there is also an event called Underexposure in Iraq which looks at the life situation of individuals in Iraq after the attack on S. A. U.S.

The film was made with liberal Somali-Dutch politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali and was due to be shown on 30 January. Van Gogh was shot and stabbed to death in November 2004 several months after receiving death threats following Submission's first broadcast on Dutch television. Two of Van Gogh's other films will be shown as planned, including the theatrical world premiere of his last feature 06/05.
The festival director Sandra den Hamer said: "The festival reflects what happens around us and within cinema itself." There is also an Iraqi-German offering entitled Underexposure, which looks at life in Iraq after Saddam Hussein.

Theo van Gogh’s controversial film was withdrawn from the Rotterdam Film Festival due to security concerns, being part of a tribute event honoring his life. It was due for screening on January 30, 2005, but he died in November 2004 after facing death threats. The festival will open with "The 10th District Court," the Top Tiger Awards for introducing new talent, and special sections on Russian and Southeast Asian productions, including an Iraqi-German film titled *Underexposure*.
tinyllama:1.1b: Murdered director Theo van Goah's controversial film Submission has been withdrawn from the Rotterdam Film Festival due to security concerns. It was one of three films shown as part of a freedom of expression event in tribute to the late filmmaker's life. The festival also featured a series of three films, including the world premieres of Submission and the last feature 06/05 by Theo van Gogh, alongside other films such as 06/05, The 10th District Court (by Raymond Depardon), and Cinema of the Future. The festival is being held under the theme of "Cinema of the World", with an emphasis on Russian and south-east Asian production, as well as a section for films produced after Saddem Hussein's death.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Rotterdam Film Festival has pulled a film featuring Theo van Gogh, the controversial director who was murdered by a Somali-Dutch man in November last year, due to security concerns. The movie was selected for screening as part of an event commemorating the late filmmaker's life and works. The films showing at the festival include Submission, directed by Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a critical portrayal of the treatment of women under Islam. It was supposed to be shown during the 10-day Rotterdam Film Festival beginning on Wednesday. However, the decision has been made not to screen it during this period as it may have posed a threat to the artist's life and well-being. In addition, there will also be screenings of other films in the festival, including two films by Van Gogh himself.
